g.text: The other big class of lead-free perovskites is the double perovskites where Pb (II) atom is
substituted by pair of Ag (I) and Metal atom of 3
valence. The most spread chemical composition
for lead-free double perovskites is Cs
thin Ô¨Ålms on the molar ratio of precursors CsBr:AgBr:BiBr
Precise solution processing allows obtaining accurate composition stoichiometry of Cs
multicomponent perovskite Ô¨Ålms, and hence good optoelectronic properties. The highly stable
thin Ô¨Ålm was used as an active material for sensor due to the fact that its electrical
properties are signiÔ¨Åcantly dependent on humidity in [
]. Fast response and recovery of this
thin Ô¨Ålmcan be explained by the reversible physical adsorption of water molecules at the
surface of thin Ô¨Ålm. A convenient solution method of synthesis to deposit high-quality Cs
Ô¨Ålmwith long lifetimes, low trap densities, and large grain sizes was developed in work [
paper, authors optimized the precursor solution using a mixture of DMSO and DMF as the solvents
and found that the introduction of a small amount of DMF is helpful to increase the grain size of
Ô¨Ålms. As a result, the incorporated excess of DMF may change the ratio
in the solution and prevent the AgBr to Ô¨Åt within the crystal lattice
and to form the impurity in Cs
. However, the use of 10% DMF resulted in formation of
double perovskite Ô¨Ålm and the PL intensity increase with preserved absorption spectrum. This was
accompanied with an increase in PL lifetimes, suggesting that reducing the trap densities is consistent
with the enlarged grain size and improvement of crystallinity. It was recently shown [
perovskite materials can be implemented in the photocatalytic systemfor dye degradation.
It was found that during photocatalytic processes, Cs
is stable in ethanol. Acceleration of
the reaction between free radicals and dye molecules indicates the unique catalytic properties of the
surface. Also, the deposition of metal clusters, such as Pt onto Cs
Along with Bi atoms, Sb and In halides are used in formation of lead-free double perovskites.
perovskite with an indirect optical bandgap of 1.64 eV was
synthesized hydrothermally in aqueous HBr acid. This all-inorganic double Cs
crystallizes in the cubic space group Fm3m with a
crystallinity and symmetry were preserved. The atomic ratios of 2.18 (Cs):1.01 (Ag):0.91 (Sb):5.90 (Br)
and existence of Sb (V) regions were found, which is consistent with the crystallographic composition
and the charge transfer from the Sb (III) to Sb (V). In the work [
hot-injection synthesis of undoped and Bi-doped Cs
The whole synthesis conditions such as temperature, number of ligands, and hydrochloric acid were
evaluated to enhance the PLQY of Bi-doped Cs
demonstrated emission at 455 nmand the Bi-doped samples exhibit a broad emission peaked at 580 nm
Another approach of substitution of Pb atoms in perovskite materials is a formation of alloyed
perovskites with mixture of metal atoms at Bsite incrystal lattice. In the work [
powder with this chemical composition was synthesized by a solid-phase reaction in evacuated Pyrex
solid powder precursors (molar ratio 2:1:1). It was also shown that
due to the formation of a stable oxide layer, which fully encapsulated and passivated the perovskite
surface, these powders and Ô¨Ålms exhibited very high stability. The surface-oxide passivation approach
reported here represented an alternate way for increasing the stability and e
], the synthesis of an air-stable zero-dimensional mixed metal halide
cation, was reported. These single crystals (Figure
